An example: when the metric units were invented, the meter was set to 1/10,000,000 the distance from the north pole to the equator, and that meter was inscribed on a metal bar. Geographers didn't slavishly use the metrologist's length; when a new length for pole-to-equator was determined, they used that. The metrologists didn't change the meter, either. Consider for a moment, that there are many indicators that could be used to quantify the progress of science - Precision of measurements for instance, or repeatability of experiments. And science has been a cornerstone of the achievements of any particular society. However, in comparison, for the arts, for the social sciences, there are no reliable indicators which could be used to quantify any such achievements. Take governance for instance - there's almost nothing you can use to quantify or compare that a democracy is better than a socialist/communist government. Or that either would be better than a monarchy. Yet at the same time we're quite certain that one is better than the other, just not in quantifiable ways.

The arts and literature have evolved, each leap providing more enriching insights into the nature of our humanity, verily answering and questioning things that are so core and central to our own personal identities or how we ought to live and conduct ourselves.

The contributions of such disciplines are so fundamental, and yet so unquantifiable. It's impossible to tell with scientific certainty which is better than which, and I'd argue from a standpoint of pure logic that any fair comparison is impossible to make.

So what happens when we inevitably discover that our set value for Planck's constant is not exactly accurate? Aren't we doing what electrical metrologists did in 1990, stopping updating our value for planck's constant? It may be better than the value from 1990 and it might be as accurate as it can be today, but I think it's more than likely that some time in the future, when we can more accurately measure the constant and when a more accurate value is needed, we will have to yet again convein and change the set value of the constant and SI units.

So are fundamental constants truly constant? In an absolute sense, yes. In a practical sense, not quite. We still only know their values within a degree of uncertainty and almost undoubtedly we will continue to change them and make them more accurate based on our ability to measure the actual, absolute sense of the constant. Our measurements may no longer be bound by physical objects, but instead will be bound by our capacity to measure fundamental constants. So, this change will not truly unbind our measurements or make them immutable as is sometimes implied, but it will redefine them.

That all being said, I'm still very much for the change. At the very least, basing the kg on planck's constant (uncertainty included) is a lot less arbitrary than basing it on some hunk of metal in France.
